pr_title: JSON-Merge-Patch and Option type to represent value (null value or non-null value) or no-value.

timeline.message: Adding Option type that can represent value (null value or non-null value) or no value.
split some(null|non-null) into empty() and of(non-null), adding ofNullable(non|non-null), rename none() to unset().

replies.bodyText:
The Option type is for "tri-state", to support explicit-null. When the user uses Option::ofNullable(null), it means value-present as explicit-null.
The JDK Optional is for "two-sate". The Optional::ofNullable(non-null) means value-present and Optional::ofNullable(null) means value-not-present.  Optional::ofNullable(null)  == Optional::empty() (isPresent() == false).
Due to above "tri-state" vs "two-state", the meaning of Option::ofNullable(null) [value-present i.e. explicit-null] and Optional::ofNullable(null) [value-not-present] is different. This indirectly affect meaning of empty as well.
Now I wonder should we remove Option::empty() from the"Option" to reduce confusion? then we'll have:
Option.of(non-null) | Option.ofNullable(value|null) == value-present
Option.unset() == value-not-present
Btw I'm still not happy with the name Option.unset(), while Option a normal type but when used in the REST API context, Option.unset() means don't change the server value.
Thoughts?
\cc @alzimmermsft  @JonathanGiles @srnagar
replies.author: anuchandy

replies.bodyText: We can borrow the JavaScript terminology for tri-state - uninitialized to represent not set, empty for initialized but with a null value and T for non-null value.

replies.bodyText:
I think that's what we have today, js_uninitialized == java_unset, Option.empty() == explicit-null. One proposed name for "unset" is "uninitialized" i.e. Option.uninitialized().
Regarding using "empty" for "null", do want empty? or given Option is for "tri-state" and "null" is a valid value, should we just expose "Option.ofNullable(null)" or  "Option.of(null)"  for explicit-null?
replies.author: anuchandy

replies.bodyText: Yeah, I was proposing we use the term uninitialized instead of unset. unset can have dual meaning which can either mean that the value is not set or that the value that is already set is reverted.

replies.bodyText: I've question-related to isPresent(), given "of(null)" represent "presence" of explicit-null, would it be confusing having this method returning false when Option is in the explicit-null state?
replies.author: anuchandy

replies.bodyText:
I think that's what isPresent() in Java's Optional does. It returns true only if the value is non-null. For everything else, it returns false. So, in our case, isPresent will return the following:
uninitialized - false
null value - false
non-null value - true
replies.author: srnagar

replies.bodyText: Also, if you think there's room for confusion with this API and is something that we don't need to add right away, we can add this later too. It just means that the user will have to do this check themselves: if(patchValue.isInitialized() && patchValue.getValue() != null). So, isPresent() is just syntactic sugar that can be introduced later, if required.
replies.author: srnagar

replies.bodyText:
thanks! yes, it's clear the purpose of "isPresent()" w.r.t Optional, given it's a two-state type. It's a bit confusing for me the behaviour of  "isPresent()" in a tri-state type.
Like you said, maybe we want to hold on to it and introduce it later once we see a need for it. At least now, I see the "Option" type is mainly used in the input model than output model, its mostly inspected in the azure-core side while serializing.

replies.bodyText:
@srnagar  I have a question - Is it a hard rule that any exception has to be wrapped in logger?
The reason for asking is - this method we will be called from serializer and will have a isInitialized check before accessing it. We will not have an output model with Option property where the user have to call getValue().
My question is, for a type used in input only model with internal guarded access, do we need a logger?. Think of it as the Optional ::value() method in an input only model.
If we still require a logger - do we need ONE logger instance per Option instance given there can be many patch Option properties OR should we prefer a static logger?
replies.author: anuchandy

replies.bodyText: @anuchandy - logging the exception before throwing is just a general guideline to help us investigate issues when customers contact us. In this case, it's debatable whether it adds too much value, so, I am fine with not logging if this doesn't help much in troubleshooting any issues. If we do want to log, then instead of creating a lot of logger instances, we can simply use a static logger.
replies.author: srnagar

replies.bodyText: thanks for the response, yep it's a bit hard to pick here - general guideline vs value addition for the specific case. Let's go without logger and add it if we ever use it in the output model.
replies.author: anuchandy

timeline.bodyText: We need a setValue() method as well. Otherwise, this will be immutable resulting in many Option objects being created to mutate the value.
timeline.author: srnagar

replies.bodyText:
was thinking about it, the current "known" use case is - This type will be used for JSON-merge-patch input only model.
The JSON-merge-patch model type will not have any required property constraints. If the user wants to clear a property in the server they set it to "Option.of(null)" and to set a value "Option.of(non-null)". The instantiation of such a model and setting of its properties highly likely to happen in one place along with an update API call.
In this known use case, I couldn't find a need to make this type mutable, unless we foresee the immediate application of this type in any other use case. So I was preferring to keep it simple & immutable, like JDK's Optional type.
Please let me know your thoughts.
replies.author: anuchandy

replies.bodyText: Yeah, I am fine with just keeping this immutable for now and we can extend it later if there's a usecase for it.
